title: Barcelona mayor appeals for calm after city’s worst night of rioting
text:
Ada Colau told protesters: ‘Barcelona does not deserve it'(Picture: Getty/Reuters)

Barcelona’s mayor has appealed for calm after the city saw its worst night of rioting since protests over the jailing of pro-independence leaders began last week.

Ada Colau told protesters ‘this cannot continue’ and urged: ‘Barcelona does not deserve it.’

Radical separatists have clashed with police over the last five nights across various Catalan cities in the wake of largely peaceful demonstrations.

But outnumbered police officers fired tear gas and water cannon at protesters on Friday night after being pelted by chunks of pavement, firecrackers and other items.

Officials have said more than 500 people – including demonstrators and police – have been injured during the riots while 150 arrests have been made.

Spanish interior minister Fernando Grande-Marlaska said on Saturday that 101 police officers were injured on Friday alone and 264 police vehicles severely damaged across the week’s riots.

Protesters gather in Via Laietana during a demonstration (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

The deterioration came on the fifth consecutive day of protests in the Catalan capital (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Local police on guard as people gather at Urquinaona square (Picture: EPA)

Demonstrators scuffle with riot police (Picture: Reuters)

Officials say there have been 150 arrests so far (Picture: Reuters)

The protests followed the jailing of Catalan leaders and politicians (Picture: SIPA USA/PA)

Source: SIPA USA

A policeman hits a protester (Picture: SIPA USA/PA)

Catalan interior chief Miquel Buch said: ‘The images of organised violence during the night in Barcelona have overshadowed the half a million people who demonstrated in a peaceful and civic manner to show they rejected the verdict.’

Deepa Khumar, a doctor from Toronto visiting for a medical conference, said the city ‘looks like a warzone’.

Catalonia’s regional president, Quim Torra, called on protesters to respect the non-violent principles of the separatist movement that has surged over the past decade.

The rioting followed largely peaceful demonstrations (Picture: ABACA/PA)

Catalonia endured its fourth general strike in two years in connection with the pro-independence process(Picture: ABACA/PA)

Hundreds of rubbish bins were set on fire during the riots (Picture: Getty Images)

A melted traffic light following (Picture: Getty Images)
